Fields.DialogueText: What's that singing?
Ah, you're the one who's singing.
Oh.... My apologies, Kapitan.

Fields.MenuText: There's no need to apologize, Nerpa.
What was that song you were singing?
Try to keep it down, will you? I need to concentrate.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh! I'm sorry!
It's a song that I like... I apologize if it bothers you.
Oh, sorry... I'll be sure to keep my voice down.
I've never heard so many apologies in such a short span of time.
It can't be that bad if it sounds so good.
*ALARM*
You call that music?
@BATTLE
Singing brings me comfort, but I'd hate to disturb anyone with it.
Po dikim stepyam Zabaikalya, gde zoloto royut v gorakh...
Brodyaga, sudbu proklinaya, Tashilsya s sumoi na plechakh.
Ah, spasibo, Kapitan! I will have to tell you more about the song sometime. The story it tells is... not so lovely.
I wouldn't worry. You've got a lovely voice.
Ah! Now there's some honest music.
Some of the worst things do. I find it helps.
I said it was honest. It doesn't have to be good.
Hey! Why is the floor wet in here?
I think it's coming from those barrels over there.
Barrels? What are we storing in those barrels?
They're just full of water...

Fields.MenuText: Dump them overboard.
What are they doing here?
You could have put up a sign! I nearly broke my neck slipping.

Fields.DialogueText: Aye-aye, Captain.
I am not sure, Captain. I think they might belong to Comrade Nerpa.
My apologies, Captain. I'll try to be more observant in the future.
Right. Make sure you've seen to the barrels and this mess by the next time I pass through.
No, please don't touch them!
My apologies, I didn't mean to yell. But those barrels... they are very important to me.
Why would you care so much about barrels of water?
That's not just any water, Kapitan. That's water from Baikal, the great lake of my homeland.
These barrels contain the lake's spirit. I can feel it.
Well, the spirit's leaking all over the deck.
Gah! Thank you for letting me know. I'll caulk these right up. We wouldn't want to have to refill them!
How in the world would we do that?
One way or another. I'll get this all mopped up.
In the meantime... why don't I tell you a joke as compensation?
A joke?
Wasn't it? But enough comedy for now. We have prey to hunt!
@BATTLE
Who built the White Sea Canal, Kapitan?
Oh, dear.
Whoever joked about our politics built the left bank. Whoever listened built the right!
*ALARM*
That sure was... educational.
What are you doing now?
We had some down time, and I thought I would make some fishing lures.
I find that intricate work with my hands is quite therapeutic.

Fields.MenuText: I would never use down time to work.
That's a very efficient way to utilize your time.
Doesn't all that squinting hurt your eyes?

Fields.DialogueText: To each their own, but I find it very relaxing.
You agree? At the end you get some nice lures to look at, maybe even sell for some extra pocket money.
It will take more than a little handcrafting to blind me!
What are you planning to do with these lures?
Why, catch fish, of course. I just love any type of fish. Fried, boiled, pickled... I can't get enough of them.
Pickled?
The taste agrees with you, Kapitan?
To each their own, Kapitan. Just like my babushka makes!
*ALARM*
Hold my lures, Kapitan. We have bigger fish to fry!
@BATTLE
I've heard it's an... acquired taste. Very acquired.
... You have a grandmother?
Oh, it's just a saying. But I technically have six.
This is a Belle thing, I assume.
Da! Have you met any of the Dekabrist-class subs?
Whee!
What's "whee"?
I'm just casting off here. I'm looking forward to some pan-fried fish tonight, prepared in a little lard. It's so nice when it's fresh out of the pan and still sizzling.
Of course, it's less nice when you burn the roof of your mouth with that first bite, ha-ha!
That's funny?
The burning sensation, not so much. But no matter how many times you've burned your mouth, you imagine that this time will be different.
I mean, who hasn't burned their mouth on hot fish before?

Fields.MenuText: Yeah, who hasn't? It happens to me on a weekly basis.
I've never done that before... and no, I'm not planning to start.
You have a very odd outlook on life, Nerpa.

Fields.DialogueText: But we just keep coming back to fresh fried fish. It is so fluffy and delicious!
Kapitan, you only live once. You need to experience life before it's gone.
If by odd you mean amusing and relatable, then yes, I agree.
*ALARM*
Da, true enough. But this at least is a problem that fire can solve!
@BATTLE
No matter how many times we find Morganas, we imagine that this time will be different.
Ugh, what's that smell?
Don't look at me, Captain.
Something around here smells terrible. Did a rat die in the galley?
Nerpa? Why does it smell so bad in here?
Oh, Kapitan - privet! I'm just pickling some fish!
Is that what that smell is?
Smell? I guess pickled fish does have a slightly pungent odor, doesn't it?
But, oh, it's so flavorful! Would you like some?

Fields.MenuText: I think I can live without it.
I'm willing to give yours a try.
I told you before, I find it disgusting.

Fields.DialogueText: You should try it, Kapitan. Life is far too short to leave anything untried.
That is wonderful! I discovered that most of the crew isn't quite so adventurous.
Some time has passed since then and now. You could have changed your mind. Call it wishful thinking.
*ALARM*
From one stinky situation to another, right, Kapitan?
Stick to politics, Nerpa.
@BATTLE
Whatever you do, Captain, don't mess up Nerpa's assembly line!
Assembly line?
Yes, don't meddle with it.
Nerpa?
Kapitan?
That sailor said you had an assembly line?
Da. I am canning the rest of the fish. It's an efficient way to store food.
Oh, really?
Please don't touch that, Kapitan!
Ack!
Mne zhal' - but I take my work very seriously. Working hard is in my blood as a Soviet.

Fields.MenuText: This canning system is not efficient at all. Changing methods would rapidly increase your pace.
I've learned by now that it's best not to question a Belle's method.
I see what you're really trying to do here. Don't hog all the fish to yourself!

Fields.DialogueText: It's as efficient as it needs to be, Kapitan. There is a reason why I am doing it this way. I don't want to disturb any of the spirits residing in this kitchen.
You are a wise person, Kapitan.
If you were hungry, you could have asked! I don't want to hog all the fish like some capitalist. Here, Captain, take a few jars.
*ALARM*
Looks as if I'll have to finish canning after the battle!
@BATTLE
Big incentive to wrap it up quick.
If it's worth doing, it's worth doing right! Besides, you might get used to the smell before you know it.
Oh, how I long to see those green lush forests that surround Lake Baikal. The ancient lake, the oldest in the world...
What have the spirits of the lake seen? What stories could they tell me?

Fields.MenuText: Nothing of too much interest, more than likely. I can't imagine anything exciting has transpired out there.
Maybe there is some sort of hidden force field keeping the forests green.
How big are the fish in that lake?

Fields.DialogueText: You don't know that, Kapitan! There's more to the land than humans can see.
You have some strange thoughts, you know that, Kapitan?
There are some sturgeons there that are bigger than either of us! How I'd love to catch one of those...
The best part of Lake Baikal is the northern section. It is nearly impossible to get there by land. To get there you must start in the south and travel up the lake.
One day I'll fish there with the lures I made!
*ALARM*
One day, but we have bigger fish to catch at the moment.
Now what kind of lure would catch them, I wonder?
@BATTLE
Hmm...
Nerpa? What's wrong?
Oh, I feel like I might never get to see the waters of Lake Baikal in person.
I feel so tied to the place, tied to its ancient spirits. That's why I keep those barrels of water on the ship.

Fields.MenuText: I'm sure you'll be able to visit one day.
What if you're right? What if you're never able to make the journey?
You keep talking about spirits. Are you saying the lake's haunted?

Fields.DialogueText: I hope you're right. Those waters call to me.
Then I will have to content myself with being there in spirit.
Not ghosts, Kapitan. Spirits. They're alive and well in everyone and everything.
Feel this cool water, Kapitan. When I submerge my arm and close my eyes, I can hear the seals barking.
Huh? I think I hear those seals too...
Molodets, Kapitan! The water does call out!
*ALARM*
Nature has a place for everything... even them.
@BATTLE
You sure you don't have some kind of connection? You're named after a seal, after all...
Not quite how it works, Kapitan. But they are unforgettably adorable!
If only the Morganas were named after cute things.
... Amin'.
I'm sorry to interrupt - particularly if that was a prayer. I didn't know you were in the habit.
Da. Once in a while it brings me peace of mind.
I wasn't aware Orthodox Christians believed in things like lake spirits.
Many do not. But I am the spirit of this submarine, aren't I? Isn't my very existence proof of objects having spirits?

Fields.MenuText: Yes, I would agree! There's no doubting that spirits exist now.
I'm still unconvinced. I like to take what I see with a healthy dose of skepticism.
I'm of the opinion you're entirely from another planet.

Fields.DialogueText: Right! You can't much argue the fact when proof is standing right in front of you.
I am unsure what further evidence you need, Kapitan. Unless you've happened to dream me!
If I was, wouldn't you think I would know what planet I was from? I feel more tied to Lake Baikal than any other place in existence.
Everyone wants to better understand the world around them. I think that's true whatever you pray to.
*ALARM*
What about the Morganas' spirits?
I must admit, there are some out there I don't wish to understand.
@BATTLE
And if you don't pray?
The spirits speak in many ways. As long as you listen, they don't make too much fuss over your methods.
Kapitan, this is exactly what I need!
A bowl? Why do you need a bowl?
This isn't just any bowl. This is carved from a burl on a tree. I need a bowl made from a tree's burl from Lake Baikal.
But I don't want to kill any tree needlessly. The tree would have to be long dead if I were to use it.

Fields.MenuText: You can't just plant another one?
Aren't bowls a little boring? Can't you pick something else?
Better to put something to good use than let it lie.

Fields.DialogueText: That doesn't undo the damage done to the first one. It's about showing respect to each and every life, not just replacing them.
Ask yourself that next time soup is served! You'll be glad to have one.
That is the true Soviet spirit!
*ALARM*
If you'll excuse me, Kapitan, I must hunt.
I'm right behind you, Nerpa.
@BATTLE
Getting musical again? You must be busy.
Since morning! Tell me what you think of this, please?
Yikes! Is that a spear?
It is! I want to hunt a narwhal, one with a tusk. Did you know that they don't all have tusks? Only the males do.
What do you plan on doing with the tusk? You've already got a spear.
I am going to trade it for a burl tree from Lake Baikal.
You really think that seems like a fair trade?
The tree that I want can only be found in the lower region of the lake. Traders wouldn't part with such wood except for something equally valuable.

Fields.MenuText: Have you ever seen a narwhal?
I don't think this is a good idea... it's far too dangerous.
Sounds like a good plan to me.

Fields.DialogueText: Not in person, but I have been studying pictures of them.
Let the Rusalki marvel at my hunt! I will face any danger to capture my prize.
Then finding the whale will be the hardest part of our journey.
*ALARM*
I hope narwhals are as easy to come across as the Rusalki are.
@BATTLE
Bezhal iz tyurmy tyomnoi nochyu, v tyurme on za pravdu stradal...
Not likely. Narwhals don't tend to hunt us.
Brr. It could stand to be a little less cold out.
I think it's pleasant.
How can you say that? You're not even wearing a coat!
I find the cold invigorating! Such temperatures are a good way to get the blood pumping.
Are you fishing? Don't tell me you're trying to catch a whale with a hook and line.
I'm trying to catch some halibut. Narwhals love halibut and squid. I had squid earlier, come to think of it.
It was delicious. Oh, I think I got one!

Fields.MenuText: Is it a whale?
Squid is very tasty. I love the texture.
I think I need another coat out here.

Fields.DialogueText: Nyet, it's a small fish. This line isn't nearly strong enough for a whale!
Your teeth bounce off it while chewing. All the challenge of eating it alive, yet with none of the risk.
Search for one if you wish. But if you miss my catch, you've only yourself to blame!
What a cute little fish! I don't think I have the heart to eat him. Might as well release him.
I'm sure he'll appreciate the gesture.
Had?
*ALARM*
Oh! I've got to find somewhere for this little friend to swim.
You've got plenty of barrels.
A saltwater fish in fresh water? Who ever heard of such a thing?
@BATTLE
You've been waiting with that spear for hours.
For a male narwhal to surface. It will look like a submarine with a tusk.
Hmmm... do you see that water moving on the starboard side?

Fields.MenuText: Yes...
I think you're seeing things.
It's too cold out here. I'm going inside.

Fields.DialogueText: Something seems... fishy to me. Ha-ha!
Nyet, the water is moving! Just be patient and watch. You'll see.
Podozhdi! Something is displacing the water.
I'm going to take a closer look.
A... closer look? Be careful, Nerpa.
I'll be fine, Kapitan.
I don't want you putting yourself in unnecessary danger.
Ah! I can see the tusk! There he is!
Nerpa? Nerpa! Did you fall? Are you all right?
Don't say those things, Kapitan. You'll panic the crew.
You didn't fall overboard?
Nyet, I jumped off to kill the whale.
You jumped off to kill the...
Good lord. You did!
Won't this be a whale of a tale? Ha-ha!
*ALARM*
At least the Morganas had the decency to wait until after I made my kill. Could you step aside while I find somewhere to set him?
@BATTLE
*SPLASH*
Happily. Find somewhere for him... far, far away from me.
Where did you learn that skill, Nerpa? Jumping off the side of the ship with a spear in hand and killing that whale was quite the sight.
I just imagined myself as my idol, Khutulun. She was a great warrior, like a seal hunting in the dark waters.
So if you believe in not upsetting spirits, why did you kill that whale?
Its death will not go to waste. I will make use of its entire body, along with trading the tusk for my tree.
I also cleaned up the site, so none of the creature would be lost to the sea.
I think fried whale will be tasty, don't you?

Fields.MenuText: Who eats whale?
Why not save time and just eat it raw?
Why do narwhals have that horn?

Fields.DialogueText: Lots of people. For some people, that's pretty much all they eat.
That sounds more efficient than it is. Have you tried chewing raw narwhal?
It's actually a large canine tooth. Almost always, it is the left tooth, but occasionally the whales will grow two large tusks. Intimidating, but no match for me!
*ALARM*
Like Khutulun, I am off to my next battle.
@BATTLE
There isn't a ship or something you look up to?
She was a mighty warrior who rode into battle at the head of Asia's strongest armies! And so do I.
And she did it without torpedoes.
Da, only imagine what she might have done with a few...
Are you feeling well, Nerpa? Are those movements you're making... voluntary?
I'm reenacting the wrestling techniques of Khutulun, my idol!
She was a niece of Kublai Khan. She was a great warrior and said no man could marry her unless he was able to best her in wrestling.
Did she ever marry?
Eventually, but not before winning thousands of horses from her suitors!
Can you imagine being a nomadic princess, competing in gymkhana on horseback?

Fields.MenuText: Are you sure she actually existed? That she isn't a character in some fairy tale?
What is gymkhana?
Why did she marry? Did her husband best her at wrestling?

Fields.DialogueText: She was well documented by travelers of her time. Where do you think your stories get their inspiration?
A grand obstacle course! On horseback it is the ultimate test of skill and endurance.
Family troubles. Reality is often anticlimactic.
*ALARM*
They haven't too far down rivers... yet. We fight here so we do not have to fight there.
@BATTLE
I want to be in top form should the Rusalki try anything. We're drawing nearer to Leningrad, and that is the ultimate prize for those Rusalki!
Not Moscow?
What's in Leningrad?
Only the hardest-working people of the whole Soviet Union!
Are we here to pick up anyone?
Nyet, we are here to drop off the narwhal tusk. Once my tree arrives, we will return.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe we can get something to eat while we're here.
I might use that time to catch up on some sleep.

Fields.DialogueText: There is raw whale left if you would like something to eat. The people of Leningrad need all the supplies they can get.
You should sleep more often, Kapitan. Even tigers sleep for sixteen hours a day!
The officer is returning! They must have dropped off my tusk.
*ALARM*
We can discuss logistics later. There's a city to defend!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Where do you find tree... dealers?

Fields.DialogueText: For a First Comrade such as me, it is easy. Humans are quite taken with us. Drop some hints in some interviews and they come to me!
And that must be the tree. Where did you say you were going to put it?
That song you keep singing, what is it?
It's an old tune. Old for me, that is. "By the Wild Steppes of the Transbaikalia."
What's it about?
It's a story about a man who escapes prison and wanders the taiga. He finds Lake Baikal and sails it until he finds his mother.
His mother states that his father is dead and that his brother is also in prison. She might also be dead.

Fields.MenuText: That sounds like my type of song.
That song is more than a little depressing, Nerpa.
Well, if I wasn't cold before, I'm cold now.

Fields.DialogueText: I love to sing it every time I work. It keeps me going.
It is depressing, but it is beautifully sad. After much searching, the man finds his mother and learns of his family.
Strange, isn't it? That one would stand firm against the Rusalki but shiver at a little verse.
Now, pass me that needle.
Needle?
Da. I am learning to scrimshaw on some of this wood I traded for.
*ALARM*
Opportunities, Kapitan! I can make beautiful patterns on many other things. Rusalka hulls, naprimer.
@BATTLE
I suppose there's no harm knowing. Though I did warn you it was a sad one.
Brodyaga Baikal pereyekhal, navstrechu - rodimaya mat...
You may think it's sad, and it is. But it's also a reminder to protect what we've still got, even when we think we've lost everything.
When you put it that way, it sounds a little more hopeful.
There's more to hope than assuming everything will turn out your way. You've got to look for opportunities to learn and grow and move forward.
Don't you do that on bone?
Never. The skeleton is the soul of a creature and must be unharmed. Would you give someone a broken gift?
Definitely not.
So it is with spirits and sacrifices.
You certainly don't let tradition slow you down.
Remind me. How far can you travel when submerged?
Only about 160 kilometers. I must remain close to the shore.
Sometimes I think of myself as a seal, hunting for prey when I dive. But they must come up for air now and again.
Speaking of fish, do you have any on you? I am feeling a bit famished, like an escaped prisoner wandering the taiga.

Fields.MenuText: No, you ate all the fish, remember?
There should still be some in the galley.
Why, yes, I keep one in each pocket for just such an occasion.

Fields.DialogueText: No matter, I can always catch more.
Otlichno. I'm commandeering it tonight!
Very funny, Kapitan, but you know what I mean! Besides, that is no way to transport fish.
*ALARM*
Looks like I'll have to sustain myself on humor. Hmm... I've got it!
Stalin loses his favorite pipe. After a while, he finds it in a drawer somewhere.
"Well, that can't be," says Beria. "I've got three men here who already confessed to the theft!"
You've got a... transgressive sense of humor.
What are they going to do? Arrest me?
@BATTLE
Make it quick.
Then Beria calls from the NKVD. "Have you found it?" he asks. Stalin says yes.
Ah, an afternoon at work on my new tree. I told you we'd find space!
Barely. How much longer are we keeping it here?
I'll take care of the tree soon enough. Much like how Lenin took care of the Whites.
Is that good or bad?
It depends on your perspective. Look at this burl. To the tree, this burl was a problem, but to us, it is a thing of beauty. Whose side do you see?

Fields.MenuText: I see our side, obviously.
I see the side of the tree. Did it have to be cut down?
Which side should I be seeing here?

Fields.DialogueText: The burl has a place in nature and should be cherished as such.
It was already cut down. We are putting it to a worthy use.
If I had all the answers, I'd be the one in the Kremlin!
I used to be able to see the other side of this room before there was a tree in the way.
Trust me, Kapitan. Once we've returned this tree to nature, you'll thank it for its service.
*ALARM*
You won't catch me thanking a tree.
@BATTLE
Why would I catch you doing it? Is it not normal to show gratitude?
I guess it depends on the recipient.
You just need practice. Let's thank these Rusalki for exploding!
It's because there's sawdust everywhere that I'm sneezing! What's going on?
I'm cutting the burl off... and cutting the tree into manageable pieces that can be used as firewood in a pinch.
We don't need firewood on a submarine.
You say that now, but when you do need firewood, you will be glad to have it.
Do you have any immediate plans for this firewood?
None that I can think of.
How about any plans to become stranded?
Not that I'm aware of.
Then we can take the firewood ashore.
As soon as we do, we will need it. But if we have it, we will never have a use for it. Isn't that funny?

Fields.MenuText: That's not how things work.
You have a valid argument. I've been alive long enough to know this is how things work.
Oh, look, raw fish!

Fields.DialogueText: If that's not how things work, then why do they always work out this way?
I think it must have to do with spirits residing in objects. They're so often impish little things.
Where!? I don't see any... hey! Don't trick me like that! We're not done here.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Achoo!
Byt' ostorozhen, Kapitan! You'll blow sawdust everywhere!
It's sort of like things always being in the last place you look.
That is how finding things tends to work, yes.
I mean that they deliberately hide from you. Haven't you ever looked for a sock?
It's an inanimate object.
That tests your patience and steels your resolve for the greater frustrations!
Like this conversation?
Just keep at it, Kapitan. You'll thank me later!
Wood shavings, too? I suppose that's an upgrade from sawdust.
Da, I am chiseling out the center of my bowl. I just love working with hand tools. I find working with my hands...
Very therapeutic, I know.
Very therapeutic, indeed... like fishing, but without tasty fish afterwards.
However, once I've finished this bowl, I'll be able to fill it with tasty fish.

Fields.MenuText: You know, you're making a bit of a mess.
Are bowls hard to make?
It doesn't seem too difficult.

Fields.DialogueText: That just means I'll have something to do after I finish this bowl. Every mess cleaned is another made.
They are not difficult. They just require time and patience.
Everything's got a balance. Too thick and you can't fit in a proper meal. Too thin and it'll fall to pieces in your hands.
*ALARM*
I'd have to cut a hole in the hull for it to float out of. On the bright side...
@BATTLE
I suppose one could cling to the tree if we sank. Wood floats, after all.
There's a bright side to sinking?
The fish could just swim right into your bowl!
What if you're fishing for a narwhal?
Then you need a bigger bowl. You ought to be careful about the ideas you give me. I might take them as challenges.
Hmm... I swear he was due back by now.
Covering for someone's watch?
I am waiting for a sailor to return with sandpaper and lacquer. The bowl's ready for polish.
It looks a bit rough on the inside.
Sandpaper first. Patience is a virtue.

Fields.MenuText: It's looking good. I can't wait to eat out of that bowl.
Patience is important for all of us, I suppose.
When people tell me to be patient, I consider that a free pass to take a nap.

Fields.DialogueText: Give a kapitan a bowl and they eat a meal. Teach a kapitan to make a bowl and they... well, you know what I mean.
Practice is as well. If you practice being patient each day, you'll gain mastery of the skill soon enough. You should try fishing!
I must confess that napping is a wonderful way to pass the time. Preferably surrounded by finished crafts.
Oh! What's that? I think I saw something.
The bowl man?
Ha! He sounds like someone who goes door to door distributing tableware.
@BATTLE
Is this leading to another Soviet joke?
It wasn't, but now we have a whole battle for me to figure it out!
*ALARM*
My hands are so raw and tired...
Then you probably ought to rest, Nerpa.
And stop now? But I feel so alive.

Fields.MenuText: Watching you is making my hands feel raw and tired.
I don't understand the Soviet mentality sometimes.
This is hypnotizing. I think I am falling asleep.

Fields.DialogueText: You can rest, Kapitan. But rest means others will see you not working as hard as they are. And that can have an effect on morale.
It's a me thing, not a Soviet thing. But it certainly does help! We're all in this together, are we not?
Don't sleep too much, Kapitan. You might miss an important technique!
Ah... I ache, but I feel so alive right now. There - I think it's ready!
Does it normally take that long?
It takes as long as it needs to. Doesn't it look beautiful, Kapitan?
It does - but did you mean for it to be asymmetrical?
It's more that it meant to be asymmetrical itself, and I agreed. It retains as much natural character as it can. This bowl embodies the spirit of Lake Baikal.
The spirit of the lake isn't symmetrical?
So obsessed with appearances! What does it do? That is what is important. That, and I will always think of the tree and the lake that it came from.
*ALARM*
I'll need to think of something to occupy my time after the battle.
@BATTLE
Maybe we can find a rock to chisel another bowl out of.
But what would I trade for it? Hmm... maybe two narwhal tusks!
Ha! Oh, how it's gotten away from me...
What's so funny?
I am thinking about this delicious fish.
It's certainly cause for happiness. I don't know about laughter.
I always start out intending to fry the entire fish, but I wind up eating half as I'm cutting it into pieces.
That fish looks sushi-grade to me.
Mmmm... melts in my mouth! You simply must try some.
This herring tastes so delicious. When I close my eyes, I can still see the ocean.
Do you think this is what seals imagine when they eat fish?

Fields.MenuText: No, seals have more important things to do.
You'd know better than anyone.
I'm convinced that you're not a Belle. You're a seal in disguise.

Fields.DialogueText: Like lounging on a rocky shore? I'm sure we could put them to work, eh, Kapitan?
Of course I would! It's in my name, after all!
I think if I were a seal, I would keep my fur coat... although then I might overheat. You may as well light me on fire then.
Mmmmm... have I told you recently how much I like fish?
*ALARM*
Heh. You might have brought it up, once or twice.
@BATTLE
You made it. You should eat it.
Mmm... Okay, you're right. I'm glad I let you bully me into this.
And gorge myself like some capitalist? No, I can tell it's been some time since you ate. I won't take no for an answer!
And now do you see? The Rusalki have smelled my cooking!
Care for an offering of fish out of this wondrous bowl? It overjoys me just to hold it.
I think about all the work I put in just to make this bowl... but then I grow sad, as the work is finished and there is no more for me to do.
Maybe I should take up weaving again. Buryat clothing is so colorful!
What type of fish do you have there? It looks like more than just herring.
Well, I was getting hungry and most of the herring disappeared before it reached the bowl. So I put some monkfish and cod in with it.

Fields.MenuText: Ugh, monkfish isn't appetizing at all.
I love the delicacy of monkfish liver. The earthy, creamy goodness is a symphony in my mouth.
I really do appreciate all of the fishing you do, Nerpa. It's a big help for the crew.

Fields.DialogueText: I can find some pickled fish for you as a substitute, if you'd like. I still have many cans left.
I am out of liver, but you are making me want to fish for more.
Ne stoit upominat'. I'm always looking for ways to assist my crew.
Oh! I have another joke for you, Kapitan.
In the Soviet Union, the government provides everything that the proletariat needs. This is why the butcher hangs the sign in his window: "No one needs meat today!"

Fields.MenuText: That's... actually quite beautiful. I wish more people thought that way.
I'm not sure I'll ever understand your sense of humor, Nerpa. But you amuse me, nonetheless.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm having trouble nailing you down. You're Soviet, aren't you?
Da! Who better to joke about the way of things?
I don't know if Stalin sees it that way.
That's his problem. Just think of how I like to stay busy. Looking for things to do isn't just about crafts, you know.
It's about figuring out how the world could be better.
Konechno! And laughing at things that don't make sense is the first step to making them sensible.
Now there is a job worth doing!
Like the Revolution, the world will awake to it in time. I would have you by my side to see it happen.
*ALARM*
Now, come on! We've got more bowls to make!
@BATTLE
